instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Does not power on
threads.message:
Hi,

I've this liquid damaged board here.

There is green and orange light on the charger.
It does charge the battery.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 8.57V
SMC powers on.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> presents.

Before the repair the board was in S3 state.

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> was missing and it was 125 Ohm.
I found <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> shorted. I changed <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>.
PIN 11 on the board was totally corroded so I fixed that with a jumper cable.

Also <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> looked pretty pad so I replaced that one too.
Here PIN 8 was missing. I fixed that also with a jumper cable.

After this, the board went into the ultrasonic cleaner.

Now, looks like all the power rails come up for a second, but the fan does not spin.

The liquid damage was around the BIOS chip.
<CHIP>U7600</CHIP> and <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>. Some was around the SMC.
I pulled the WLED driver because it looked really bad.

If I'm not mistaken Y1905 was oscillating prior the repair. Now there is 0.9V but it does not oscillate.

I also pulled the BIOS chip because PIN 8 was totally corroded.
Even without the BIOS chip fan doesn't move.

After this I reballed the SMC. Didn't help anything.

If I leave the board on the charger <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> gets warm. I changed it just for the hell of it.

Any idea?

Thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Does not power on
threads.message: It will power cycle without ROM chip. Check the resistors in series with the ROM data lines. CPU Vcore should be pulsing too

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Does not power on
threads.message:
I checked the resistors I changed those which looked bad, but still nothing.
I can see that CPU VCORE comes up for a sec. Again, fan didn't spin. Not even just for a millisecond.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Does not power on
threads.message: It is power cycling. Could be anything, the usual is <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and resistors around it and the clock chip. Was pin 8 on the ROM fixed? ROM must be present for the board to power up.
